*div1 type="summary"* *p*Charles W. Webber to Austin, Columbia, Tenn., February 15, 1833. Biographical. Introducing William K. Hill.*/p* */div1*
*div1 type="body"*
*p**location_mentioned*Columbia Tennessee*/location_mentioned**/p* *p**date_mentioned n="02-15-1833">February 15th 1833*/date_mentioned*.*/p* *p*Dr. Sir*/p*
*p*This letter will be handed you by my friend *person_mentioned*Col. William K Hill */person_mentioned*of this place, he is on a visit to *location_mentioned*Texas */location_mentioned*for the purpose of making a permanent location for himself and *person_mentioned*family*/person_mentioned*; You will find him a *person_mentioned*gentleman of intelligence*/person_mentioned*, and every way worthy of your attention and friendship, he has been for several years *person_mentioned*clerk to the Senate of this State*/person_mentioned* And discharged his duties with approved ability and skill;*/p*
*p*My name may almost be forgotten to you, but I anticpate it will call up some pleasant recollections of days long gone by, days that were probably the happiest of our lives, for it is true that the days of our boyhood are freer from care, pain, disappointment, and regrets than those that succeed them—*/p*
*p*I well remember the thoughtlessness and gayety of your life when boarding at my fathers in *location_mentioned*Kentucky */location_mentioned*and going to school to *location_mentioned*old Wilson */location_mentioned*; you were then happy, particularly so when you had your flute in your hand, and seemed not to care for the future, Your pursuits, thoughts, feelings, and all, are now changed; Whether your pleasure or happiness may have been promoted by the vicissitude— or not you can easily answer. But enough of moralizing. I see from the *location_mentioned*papers of the day*/location_mentioned* that you anticipate a convention in *location_mentioned*Texas*/location_mentioned*, and intend probably to declare yourselves Independent of *location_mentioned*Mexico*/location_mentioned*. I heartily wish you may succeed in the attempt and be enabled to maintain that Independence— If you should succeed and establish a *location_mentioned*literal Republic*/location_mentioned*, thousands in the West would immediately become citizens of it.*/p*
*p*I have long had a great desire to settle in *location_mentioned*Texas*/location_mentioned*, but am restrained from doing so by reason of the form of the *person_mentioned*government */person_mentioned*principally, I most cordially wish you health, happiness and prosperity,—I should be much gratified to receive from you a detailed statement of the views and objects of the *person_mentioned*citizens */person_mentioned*in having a convention and declaring themselves Independent, is it any part of their object to connect themselves with the *location_mentioned*United States*/location_mentioned*, or do they intend to form a seperate Independent government unconnected with any other. Will you please answer me.*/p*
*p**person_mentioned*Charles W. Webber*/person_mentioned**/p* *p*[Addressed:] *person_mentioned*Stephen F. Austin Esq.*/person_mentioned* *location_mentioned* Province of Texas*/location_mentioned**/p*
*/div1*
